{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3135669,"name":"","username":"Alastor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f08c70/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-28T23:47:58.913Z","cooked":"

Where can I find a long (3"+) adapter for a redline motor to a .5 inch hex shaft?

I want to direct drive for small size for the smaller scale of my teams robot this year. The motors are mounted on an intake that rotates up and down. The motors would direct drive a sprocket driving other sprockets. 2 motors, 1 for each side of the intake. The only other option is to get gearboxes and run a long hex shaft from those or run hub adaptors.

All I can find are 1" long but I have found more adaptors but for different sizes of output shafts.

Too short example: 8mm to 1/2 hex shaft adapter

Length I need but wrong size (Different adaptor size): 0.125 in. Round to 0.5 in. Hex Adapter Shaft

any help is appreciated.

Hex Adapter Shaft - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":13}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56852,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/redline-motor-output-shaft-to-5-inch-hex-adaptor-3-long/425000/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3135695,"name":"Gordon Walsh","username":"GordonW","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/7feea3/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-29T00:48:55.738Z","cooked":"

If you have a lathe, you might be able to use a no. 9 or no. 10 drill bit (or no.9 or 0.195" reamer, or appropriately sized metric tooling) to make a hole in the end of a piece of hex shaft that is somewhere between a press fit and gap-filling retaining compound. Alternatively, you could make such a hole, then slit the shaft and use a shaft collar to clamp onto the motor shaft.

If you don’t have a lathe, the central 5 mm hex hole of REV UltraHex (or on AM) may possibly also work with the same methods, though less contact area certainly doesn’t help.

Alter-alternatively, if you can find a bushing or tube that would fill the space between the 5mm shaft and a larger hole (e.g. 1/4" for the AM Toughbox output shaft) you may be in business. If it is made of plastic or soft/thin metal, you may even be able to use a 3/16" ID and stretch it over the 5 mm shaft (maybe this stuff if the tolerances work out?).

If I understand what you are trying to do correctly, I’d recommend not doing what you are attempting to do. Shafts on 775s do not handle side-loads very well, and certainly not side loads that are 3” away from the face of the motor. Perhaps you are suggesting that you need that length to support the end of the shaft in a bearing - if so, that will certainly help. But I’d still be very concerned about mounting a sprocket directly on that shaft.

Also, the speed that sprocket will be spinning will be VERY fast (21,000 RPM free speed!) with very little torque. Are you sure that’s what you want to be doing? That’s why you typically see a gearbox, often planetary, attached to these motors.

Finally, if you are too space constrained for a planetary gearbox, you may have space to put a pinion on the motor ( like 12 Tooth 32 DP 5 mm Round Bore Steel Pinion Gear - AndyMark, Inc) and drive a small 32 DP gear right next to it.
